conclusion: Both vehicles start braking at the same time, initially 30 meters apart, truck starts at 40 m/s, bus at 30 m/s, both decelerate linearly at different rates.
Truck initial velocity is 40 m/s, reaches 0 m/s at t = 20 s.
Bus initial velocity is 30 m/s, reaches 0 m/s at t = 30 s.
Distance between vehicles at time t: D(t) = 30 - 10t + 0.5t².
Derivative of distance function: D'(t) = -10 + t, set to zero gives t = 10 seconds.
Second derivative D''(t) = 1 > 0, confirming minimum distance at t = 10s.
Truck initially faster at 40 m/s, decelerates more quickly at 2 m/s², speeds equal at t = 10s.
Maximum distance occurs at t = 0 or when both vehicles stop.
At t = 30s, truck traveled 400 meters, bus traveled 450 meters, final distance is 80 meters.
At t = 20s, both vehicles traveled 400 meters, distance is 30 meters.
Maximum distance between vehicles during braking is 80 meters at t = 30 seconds.
